Definition at line 470 of file GrPolygon.cpp.

bool GrPolygon::CheckTJunc ( const GrPolygon &  polygon,
float  epsilon 
)

we can't perform this on skinned vertices! How would we determine what bone(s) the any new verts are influenced by?

if both polygons aren't edge polygons, then there is no possibility of a t-junction.

determine the squared epsilon.

check for a t-junction.

get the current current vertex in the other polygon.

if the current point on the other polygon resides on one of our vertices, ignore it.

check for a point residing on the current edge.

allocate and generate a new vertex. Weld it's position to the other polygon's position.

add new vertices. all done.

make sure it's clear on exit since this variable is static.

return true if we've added vertices to fix t-junctions.

Definition at line 134 of file GrPolygon.h.

float GrPolygon::GetArea (  )  const

returns the area of the triangle.

fan the polygon and calculate area for each triangle.

get edge vectors of the current triangle.

skip this triangle if one of the edges is 0 length as it obviously has no area.

calculate the area of the current triangle.

return the total area.

Definition at line 117 of file GrPolygon.h.

bool GrPolygon::Intersect ( SRayIntersectInfo &  info,
const SVec3 &  rayStart,
const SVec3 &  rayDir,
float  maxDist 
) const

performs a fast intersection test on the polygon using the ray passed in. This is faster than iterating through triangles and using the ray's test routine because it avoids a lot of SVec3->MVec3 implicit conversions.

calculate the point on the triangle's plane along the ray.

skip test if we're facing the direction of the ray (backfacing to the ray).

get the first position in the polygon.

calculate the distance along the ray to the plane.

calculate where we intersect the plane the triangle lies on.

using the face normal, find the dominant axis so we can perform our triangle-ray tests in 2D.

we only need to go through this loop twice... if we fail the first two times, then we know the third axis is the dominant one.

choose an axis to throw away and solve in 2D.

now fan the polygon and perform ray tests with each triangle.

get the other points on the current triangle.

calculate the barycentric coordinates.

return true if we're inside the triangle.

if we got here, then we don't intersect with any triangles in the polygon.

Definition at line 307 of file GrPolygon.cpp.

float GrPolygon::IntersectFast ( const SVec3 &  rayStart,
const SVec3 &  rayDir,
float  maxDist 
) const

calculate the point on the triangle's plane along the ray.

skip test if we're facing the direction of the ray (backfacing to the ray).

get the first position in the polygon.

calculate the distance along the ray to the plane.

divide distance by cos theta.

calculate where we intersect the plane the triangle lies on. note that this becomes rayStart + distance * rayDir - pt0, which is the same as vec + distance * rayDir where vec = rayStart - pt0.

choose an axis to throw away and solve in 2D.

now fan the polygon and perform ray tests with each triangle.

get the other points on the current triangle.

calculate the barycentric coordinates.

return true if we're inside the triangle.

if we got here, then we don't intersect with any triangles in the polygon.

Definition at line 399 of file GrPolygon.cpp.

bool GrPolygon::IsCoplanar ( const MPlane &  plane,
float  epsilon 
) const

checks to see if the polygon is coplanar to the plane passed in.

if we're facing wildly different directions, return false.

go through all vertices checking to see if we're coplanar.

if we made it through all vertices, then we're coplanar.

less then 3 verts, then its definately degenerate.

Definition at line 672 of file GrPolygon.cpp.

bool GrPolygon::IsEdgePolygon ( const MPlane &  plane,
float  planeDistEpsilon 
) const

checks to see if the polygon has an edge on the plane passed in.

this function returns true if an edge lies on the plane passed in. Since we know the polygon will be convex, if two or more vertices lie on the plane in question, then we are an edge polygon.

if we on the plane and there are two vertices on the plane so far, then we know we have an edge polygon.

Definition at line 736 of file GrPolygon.cpp.

bool GrPolygon::IsNeighbor ( const GrPolygon &  polygon,
float  epsilon = 0.001f 
) const

returns line segments that lie on the plane passed in.

returns true if the polygon passed in is a neighbor of this polygon.

This function checks edges to see if they match up. The edges must be going opposite direction or else they are not considered neighbors.

go through each edge in this polygon.

go through each edge in the polygon passed in.

check to see if our vertices match up and the edge direction is opposing.

if we get here then the polygon is not a neighbor.

int GrPolygon::Split ( GrPolygon &  front,
GrPolygon &  back,
const MPlane &  plane,
float  planeDistEpsilon 
) const

splits the polygon by a plane. The return value is 1 if there is only a front polygon, -1 if there is only a back polygon, and 0 if there is both a front and back polygon.

get the number of vertices.

place to store vertices in front and in back.

get the starting vertex.

get the starting side.

are we entirely coplanar?

choose the side the polygon is facing.

simply go through the vertices and classify.

update previous vertex info.

if we're not coplanar, we need to create the polygon.
